title: Jorge Thomas
text:
Hello there
I‚Äôm Jorge and I like espresso brewed with light roast beans. I subscribe to Johnny Cash‚Äôs definition of paradise:



‚ÄúThis morning, with her, having coffee.‚Äù



Professionally I am Electrical Engineer fond of sustainable energy sources; that means uncertainty, risk and probabilities, you know weather. Somehow, I‚Äôve always managed to end up doing what I love the most: the development of data-driven models either for providing business intelligence or supporting control systems.
I don‚Äôt bike but I live in Karlsruhe. If you want to know how I got into what today is Data Science click on the About tab. If you want to talk about data science, music or coffee instead, just drop me an email.
Have a nice day or evening.


J. Thomas

title: About
text:
My data journey started back in the mid 2000s, working as a Reliability Engineer of Power Systems for the operator of the world‚Äôs fourth biggest hydroelectric power plant Guri. The objective was ambitious:

Dynamic monitoring of the risk of blackouts with probabilistic KPIs.

At that time the position Data Scientist didn‚Äôt exist, but some books in the realm of Data Mining and Emerging Computing Methods trying to organise and formalise the field. However, the area of Survival Analysis, specifically Reliability and Risk were pretty matured due to their importance for the industry.
Going forward with a stochastic thinking in an organisation with a lack of statistical culture and less amounts of data wasn‚Äôt easy, relying only on a mixture of internal ERP data, world surveys and standards. A continuous push towards a data culture from top-level management was key, and it still is!

title: About
text: Dipl.-Ing. Electrical Engineering

title: Projects
text:
Welcome to my portfolio!
Here you‚Äôll find a mixture of professional, prototype and fun projects like Kaggle competitions. Technologies I‚Äôve used are highlighted. There are four main categories:

title: Projects
text:
Machine Learning

Advanced regression techniques with visual analytics
In this classic Kaggle project you can follow my workflow where I‚Äôll give you some tips along the way, developing pipelines on the ETL phase of the DS cycle, as well as a tidy presentation on the EDA supported on visual analytics. Among the technologies I used are R with the state-of-the-art Tidyverse and Tidymodels packages. Quarto is the publishing system.

title: Projects
text:
Deep Learning
It is known that the most common type of dataset found in the industry is the tabular one. In this regard ML‚Äôs non-parametric methods with ensembling via bagging or boosting are king.
However, for datasets with high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) like image recognition and language translation, DL methods are the best.

title: Projects
text:
Data Visualisation

E2E Dashboards with Tableau
Click here to see the dashboards on the Tableau Public website.

title: Projects
text:
Machine Learning:

Hierarchical clustering of daily load profiles
In the modern world of sector-coupled utilities, i.e., gas, water, heat & power distribution, time-series always have a very strong daily seasonality. Sequential data of demand are a strong function of calendar factors like hour and day type. Based on a famous proceeding with more than fourty citations in patents, I developed this heriarchical clustering algorithm as a tool to identify the most relevant daily patterns, e.g., weekends, holidays, workdays and anomalous profiles.

title: Projects

Survival Analysis
My professional entry point to what at that time was Data Mining, specifically in the area of reliability and risk assessment of power systems.

title: Projects
text:
Interactive Dashboards

IoT-Dashboards for energy management with Tableau
I designed these IoT-Dashboards with monitoring and BI purposes using Tableau Desktop. I also developed the whole E2E pipeline using technolgies like InfluxDB, SQLite, Python and Tableau Bridge to keep the dashboards up to date on a half-hour basis. This was the final part of the project dynOpt-En.


E2E automated energy reports for smart buildings
In 2019 for the EffMon project, I developed a set of functions to comunicate with Fraunhofer‚Äôs FROST-Server, an Open Source implementation of the OGC SensorThings API. Using Markdown publishing technologies, as well as libraries like ggplot, I automatised the entire KPI calculations and visualisations for reporting and management of the entire energy demand of the Fraunhofer IOSB building in Karlsruhe, including district heating, hot water, cooling tower and power. Click above on the title to see a video of the results!

title: About
text: Data was not everywhere

title: Projects
text:
Supervised Learning

- Machine Learning:

title: Projects
text:
Unsupervised Learning
Very often we have to do some previous ML for the sake of ML. Yes, that means performing some auto-labelling or at least identifying some possible ones, i.e., discovering patterns in the feature space.

- Machine Learning:

Hierarchical clustering of daily load profiles






In the modern world of sector-coupled utilities, time-series always have a very strong daily seasonality. Sequential data of demand are a strong function of calendar factors like hour and day type. Based on a proceeding with more than fourty patents, I developed this hierarchical clustering algorithm as a tool to identify the most relevant daily patterns, e.g., weekends, holidays, workdays and anomalous load profiles.

title: Projects
text:
Supervised Learnin

Machine Learning:

Advanced regression techniques with visual analytics
In this classic Kaggle project you can follow my workflow where I‚Äôll give you some tips along the way, developing pipelines on the ETL phase of the DS cycle, as well as a tidy presentation on the EDA supported on visual analytics. Among the technologies I used are R with the state-of-the-art Tidyverse and Tidymodels packages. Quarto is the publishing system.



Deep Learning:
It is known that the most common type of dataset found in the industry is the tabular one. In this regard ML‚Äôs non-parametric methods with ensembling via bagging or boosting are king. However, for big datasets with high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) like image recognition and language translation, DL methods are unbeatable.


Survival Analysis:
My professional entry point to what at that time was Data Mining, specifically in the area of reliability and risk assessment of power systems.

title: About
text:
My data journey started in 2005, working as a Reliability Engineer of Power Systems for the operator of the world‚Äôs fourth biggest hydroelectric power plant Guri.
At that time there was no such a position as Data Scientist, but some books in the realm of Data Mining and Emerging Computing Methods trying to organise and formalise the field. However, the area of Survival Analysis, specifically Reliability and Risk were pretty matured, given their importance for the industry.
Going forward in an organisation with a lack of statistical culture and a probabilistic thinking with less ammounts of data wasn‚Äôt easy, relying only on a mixture of internal ERP‚Äôs data, world surveys and standards. A continuous push towards a data culture from the mangement above was key, and it still is!

title: About
text:
My data journey started back in the mid 2000s, working as a Reliability Engineer of Power Systems for the operator of the world‚Äôs fourth biggest hydroelectric power plant Guri. The objective was ambitious:

Dynamic monitoring of the risk of blackouts with probabilistic KPIs.

At that time the position Data Scientist didn‚Äôt exist, but some books in the realm of Data Mining and Emerging Computing Methods trying to organise and formalise the field. However, the area of Survival Analysis, specifically Reliability and Risk were pretty matured due to their importance for the industry.
Going forward with a stochastic thinking in an organisation with a lack of statistical culture and less amounts of data wasn‚Äôt easy, relying only on a mixture of internal ERP data, world surveys and standards. A continuous push towards a data culture from top-level management was key, and it still is!

title: Projects
text:
Data Extraction and Scrapping

Global Forecast System decoder


I wrote this application in .NET C#. It scraps the ftp-site of NCEP‚Äôs Global Forecast System, GFS - Numeric Weather Prediction model (NWP). It also decodes (degribs) and disaggregates the weather forecast variables of any configured pair of geo-coordinates.

title: Projects
text:
Delivering an ML/AI strategy


‚ÄúWe have a data lake; what can we do?‚Äù I developed this demo project with the objective of thoroughly learning a methodology to assess impactful AI implementations in real business projects (Use Cases). I used tools like Storyboards, Prioritisation Grids, 5 V‚Äôs Framework and Potter‚Äôs Boxes, all this within a ship & iterate philosophy in order to gather quick feedback.

Keywords: AI for Business, AI Architecture, Data Strategy, Data Products.

title: Projects
section: IoT-Dashboards for energy management with Tableau
text:
IoT-Dashboards for energy management with Tableau


I designed these IoT-Dashboards with monitoring and BI purposes using Tableau Desktop. I also developed the whole E2E pipeline using technologies like InfluxDB, SQLite, Python and Tableau Bridge to keep the dashboards up to date on a half-hour basis. This was the final part of the project dynOpt-En.
Keywords: Data Engineering, Tableau, Dashboards, Monitoring, IoT, Energy Management.

title: Projects
section: E2E automated energy reports for smart buildings
text:
E2E automated energy reports for smart buildings










In 2019 for the EffMon project, I developed a set of functions to communicate with Fraunhofer‚Äôs FROST-Server, an Open Source implementation of the OGC SensorThings API. Using Markdown publishing technologies, as well as libraries like ggplot, I automatised the entire KPI calculations and visualisations for reporting and management of the entire energy demand of the Fraunhofer IOSB building in Karlsruhe, including district heating, hot water, cooling tower and power. Click on the image to see a video of the results.
Keywords: Advanced Analytics, Reports Automation, Monitoring, IoT, Energy Management.

title: Projects
text:
Global Forecast System decoder


I wrote this application in .NET C#. It scraps the ftp-site of NCEP‚Äôs Global Forecast System, GFS - Numeric Weather Prediction model (NWP). It also decodes (degribs) and disaggregates the weather forecast variables of any configured pair of geographical coordinates.

Keywords: Software Development, Weather Data, Photovoltaic Power Forecasting.

title: Projects
section: Advanced regression techniques with visual analytics
text:
Advanced regression techniques with visual analytics










Follow my workflow for a top 10% solution for this open Kaggle competition, predicting the house prices in Ames. I‚Äôll give you tips along the way, developing pipelines on the ETL phase, as well as a clean presentation on the EDA supported on the best visuals. I used R with the state-of-the-art Tidyverse and Tidymodels metapackages. Quarto is the publishing system.

Keywords: Machine Learning, Supervised Learning, Regression, Elastic-Net, XGBoost, Ensemble Models.

title: Projects
text:
Forecasting heat demand in buildings


With today‚Äôs advances on remote sensing, optimal energy management can be performed in the cloud. This is the maxima of project dynOpt-En, where I developed the two-days-ahead forecasting module for the MPC optimiser. Training a Generalised Additive Model (GAM) and using the Dark Sky API, free at that time, I manage to retrieve the weather variables from Numeric Weather Prediction models (NWP) needed as features.

Keywords: Machine Learning, Supervised Learning, Time-Series, Forecasting, GAM.

title: Projects
section: Water demand prediction with LSTMs for pumps control
text:
Water demand prediction with LSTMs for pumps control










In this project my main task was the hyper-parameters optimisation. Using Python‚Äôs scikit-learn and TensorFlow wrapped in the Keras API, I was able to determine the optimal batch size and the number of units for the LSTM network.

Keywords: Deep Learning, Supervised Learning, Time-Series, Forecasting, LSTMs.

title: Projects
section: Electrical substation reliability assessment using the Monte Carlo chronological method: A Real Case Evaluation
text:
Electrical substation reliability assessment using the Monte Carlo chronological method: A Real Case Evaluation


With 4.5/5 ‚≠ê review score, the almost 20 years-old Matlab code, which is a simplified version of the full project, has helped more than 3000 practitioners and students. I used the Monte Carlo Chronological Technique to simulate an artificial history of failures of the components of power substations, estimating load point stochastic KPIs like Estimated Energy Not Supplied (EENS) and Estimated Duration of Load Curtailment (EDLC).
Keywords: Survival Analysis, Risk, Stochastic Processes, Markov Chains, Monte Carlo Simulation, Business Intelligence.

title: Projects
section: Hierarchical clustering of daily load profiles
text:
Hierarchical clustering of daily load profiles










In the modern world of sector-coupled utilities, time-series always have a very strong daily seasonality. Sequential data of demand are a strong function of calendar factors like hour and day type. Based on a proceeding with more than fourty patents, I developed this hierarchical clustering algorithm as a tool to identify the most relevant daily patterns, e.g., weekends, holidays, workdays and anomalous load profiles.

Keywords: Machine Learning, Unsupervised Learning, Classification, Time-Series, Patterns.

title: About
text:
My data journey started back in the mid 2000s, working as a Reliability Engineer of Power Systems for the operator of the world‚Äôs fourth biggest hydroelectric power plant Guri. The objective was ambitious:

Dynamic monitoring of the risk of blackouts with probabilistic KPIs.

At that time the position Data Scientist didn‚Äôt exist, but some books in the realm of Data Mining and Emerging Computing Methods trying to organise and formalise the field. However, the area of Survival Analysis, specifically Reliability and Risk were pretty matured due to their importance for the industry.
Going forward with a stochastic thinking in an organisation with a lack of statistical culture and less amounts of data wasn‚Äôt easy, relying only on a mixture of internal ERP data, world surveys and standards. A continuous push towards a data culture from top-level management was key, and it still is!
